questions.text: What is the correct order of insertion of muscles from near to far from the limbus?

options.label: A
options.text: Lateral rectus > Superior rectus > Medial rectus > Inferior rectus

options.label: B
options.text: Medial rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus > Inferior rectus

options.label: C
options.text: Medial rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus

options.label: D
options.text: Superior rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Medial rectus

questions.correct_answer: C. Medial rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Medial rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct insertion order of extraocular muscles from the limbus, following the spiral of Tillaux, is Medial rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus .
  • ➤ Medial rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus

questions.text: A 16-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of severe itching, redness, and photophobia in both eyes for the past few weeks. He mentions that his symptoms worsen during the spring and summer months. The patient denies any history of contact lens wear or recent eye trauma. His visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes, and intraocular pressure is within normal limits. Given the clinical presentation which of the following findings you would expect?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Trantas spots

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trantas’s spots are a key diagnostic feature in VKC, particularly when symptoms such as severe itching and seasonal exacerbation are present in young male patients.
  • ➤ Trantas’s spots

questions.text: The following ocular structure is not derived from surface ectoderm:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sclera

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sclera is derived from the neural crest, while the crystalline lens, corneal epithelium, and epithelium of lacrimal glands are derived from the surface ectoderm .
  • ➤ sclera
  • ➤ surface ectoderm

questions.text: What is incorrect about this lesion?

options.label: A
options.text: Consist of head, neck, and body

options.label: B
options.text: Simple excision can reduce recurrence by 90-95%

questions.correct_answer: B. Simple excision can reduce recurrence by 90-95%
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Simple excision can reduce recurrence by 90-95%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Simple excision of a pterygium has a high recurrence rate (up to 80%). Techniques like conjunctival transplantation are preferred to reduce recurrence by addressing limbal stem cell deficiency .
  • ➤ limbal stem cell deficiency

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents with a 3-day history of seeing "spots" floating around in her right eye. Today, she notes streaks of light in the same eye accompanied by a "shadow" in her peripheral vision that moves when looking up and down. Her medical history is significant for migraine headaches; however, she has never had such visual symptoms with her headaches. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Retinal Detachment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of floaters, flashes, and a curtain-like shadow in the peripheral vision are classic signs of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment and should prompt immediate evaluation to prevent permanent vision loss.
  • ➤ floaters, flashes, and a curtain-like shadow in the peripheral vision
  • ➤ rhegmatogenous retinal detachment

questions.text: Identify the condition:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Angular conjunctivitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Angular conjunctivitis is an inflammation at the corners of the eyes, typically caused by Moraxella lacunata or sometimes Staphylococcus aureus , and is treated with zinc oxide or tetracycline ointment.
  • ➤ Angular conjunctivitis
  • ➤ Moraxella lacunata
  • ➤ Staphylococcus aureus
  • ➤ zinc oxide
  • ➤ tetracycline

questions.text: When managing a patient with elevated intraocular pressure uncontrolled by medication, which of the following would be ideal candidate for Argon laser trabeculoplasty?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Primary open glaucoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Argon laser trabeculoplasty (ALT) is primarily indicated for Primary Open Angle Glaucoma (POAG) , where the trabecular meshwork is accessible and can be modified to improve aqueous outflow.
  • ➤ Argon laser trabeculoplasty (ALT)
  • ➤ Primary Open Angle Glaucoma (POAG)

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with severe eye pain, redness, and sensitivity to light in their right eye. They have a history of Herpes Zoster infection on the same side of their face a few weeks ago. On examination, you notice decreased visual acuity and inflammation in the eye. Which of the following complications of Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus is the patient most unlikely experiencing?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Keratoconjunctivitis sicca.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While keratitis, uveitis, and necrotizing retinitis are common and significant complications of Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus , keratoconjunctivitis sicca (dry eye) is less commonly associated as an acute complication and tends to be a chronic sequela.
  • ➤ keratitis, uveitis, and necrotizing retinitis
  • ➤ Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus
  • ➤ keratoconjunctivitis sicca (dry eye)

questions.text: A 38-year-old female patient presents with loss of vision in both eyes. On examination normal pupillary responses are seen with normal fundus. VER shows extinguished response. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cortical blindness

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cortical blindness is characterized by visual loss with a normal pupillary response and normal fundus examination , with extinguished VER response confirming the lack of visual processing in the occipital cortex.
  • ➤ Cortical blindness
  • ➤ normal pupillary response
  • ➤ normal fundus examination
  • ➤ extinguished VER response

questions.text: A 54-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of right-sided visual field loss. Upon examination, his both pupil constricts briskly when a bright light is shone into his eyes from left side, but his pupils do not constrict when light is shone into his eyes from Right Side. Which structure lesion would lead to this type of pupillary response?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Optic tract

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wernicke’s hemianopic pupil (loss of pupillary light response on one side) is a characteristic sign of a lesion in the optic tract , leading to a contralateral homonymous hemianopia.
  • ➤ Wernicke’s hemianopic pupil
  • ➤ lesion in the optic tract

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presented with complaints of defective vision in the right eye associated with erythropsia and cyanopsia. On examination it was seen that his pupil was jet black and the Purkinje image test revealed only two images. What is likely to be the conclusion after performing retinoscopy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) High hypermetropia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of aphakia , patients often experience high hypermetropia with symptoms such as erythropsia, cyanopsia , and a reduction in Purkinje images to two due to the absence of the lens.
  • ➤ aphakia
  • ➤ high hypermetropia
  • ➤ erythropsia, cyanopsia
  • ➤ reduction in Purkinje images to two

questions.text: The Fovea centralis is responsible for the visual acuity of a person. How much is it’s diameter?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1.5 mm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The fovea centralis has a diameter of approximately 1.5 mm and is essential for high-acuity vision. The foveal avascular zone (FAZ) within it has a diameter of 500 microns .
  • ➤ fovea centralis
  • ➤ 1.5 mm
  • ➤ foveal avascular zone (FAZ)
  • ➤ 500 microns

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of discharge, pain, and redness in his left eye. He states that his ophthalmologist surgically placed a "filter" in this eye 5 years ago to control his glaucoma. Visual acuity is 20/200 in this eye. Inspection reveals a very injected and swollen eye. You also note a very milky layer of fluid accumulating in the anterior chamber (Figure). What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: C
options.text: Hyperacute Bacterial Conjunctivitis Caused By Neisseria Gonorrhea

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bacterial Endophthalmitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bacterial endophthalmitis is a serious intraocular infection that can follow glaucoma drainage implant surgery, especially in cases with poor hygiene or infection at the implant site. It presents with pain, discharge, severe redness, and hypopyon.
  • ➤ Bacterial endophthalmitis

questions.text: A 42-year-old female presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of decreased vision and distortion in her left eye for the past few months. Upon indirect ophthalmoscopic examination, you notice a bulging area in the posterior pole of the left eye, along with thinning of the sclera. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) confirms the presence of posterior staphyloma. Visual acuity in the left eye is 20/80. Intraocular pressure is within normal limits, and there are no signs of retinal detachment or other complications. In which of the following conditions the given scenario is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Myopia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Posterior staphyloma is a structural change associated with pathological myopia , where there is thinning and bulging of the sclera at the posterior pole, often confirmed by OCT.
  • ➤ Posterior staphyloma
  • ➤ pathological myopia

questions.text: Where does the marked muscle originate from?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Annulus of Zinn

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lateral rectus muscle originates from the Annulus of Zinn and is responsible for the abduction of the eye.
  • ➤ lateral rectus muscle
  • ➤ Annulus of Zinn

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient presents with complaints of gradual loss of peripheral vision over the past few months. On examination, intraocular pressure is found to be elevated. Visual field testing reveals characteristic defects consistent with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG). Which of the following treatment options is the most appropriate initial therapy for managing this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) PG analogues

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prostaglandin analogues are the first-line treatment for primary open-angle glaucoma due to their efficacy in reducing intraocular pressure, once-daily dosing, and good patient compliance profile.

questions.text: A 68-year-old female presents with gradual onset of blurred vision, glare sensitivity, and difficulty with night driving over the past year. On examination, visual acuity is 20/80 in the right eye and 20/60 in the left eye. Slit-lamp examination reveals bilateral opacification of the crystalline lenses with cortical and nuclear changes. Fundoscopic examination is unremarkable, with no evidence of retinal pathology. Which of the following surgical options is most commonly used for the treatment of this patient's condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Intracapsular cataract extraction plus intraocular lens implantation

options.label: C
options.text: Extracapsular cataract extraction plus intraocular lens implantation

questions.correct_answer: A. Phacoemulsification plus intraocular lens implantation
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Phacoemulsification plus intraocular lens implantation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phacoemulsification with intraocular lens implantation is the standard and most common surgical technique for cataract removal due to its minimal invasiveness, rapid recovery time, and effectiveness in visual restoration.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female of thin stature, presented to the OPD with redness, irritation and watering in both eyes for the past 1 month. She had a history of loss of appetite & weight. Examination showed a pinkish white nodule with ulcerated apex at the limbus. What would be the investigation of choice?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mantoux test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of chronic ocular inflammation with systemic symptoms like weight loss and anorexia, a pinkish-white limbal nodule (phlyctenule) may suggest phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis due to a hypersensitivity reaction to tubercular antigens. The Mantoux test is the investigation of choice to assess underlying tuberculosis.

questions.text: The finding that all three types of Duane’s syndrome share is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Globe retraction with adduction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Globe retraction with adduction due to co-contraction of the medial and lateral rectus muscles is a defining characteristic of Duane’s syndrome present across all three types.
  • ➤ Globe retraction with adduction

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl with myopia started using her elder sister’s contact lenses. This sharing of contact lens may lead to the spread of which of the following infections?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acanthamoeba

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sharing contact lenses can lead to serious eye infections, with Acanthamoeba keratitis being a significant risk due to improper hygiene practices. Proper disinfection and avoidance of shared lenses are essential to prevent this sight-threatening infection.
  • ➤ Acanthamoeba keratitis

questions.text: A 78-year-old male patient with a history of Right Eye Hyper­mature Cataract presents with a 2 day history of ciliary congestion, photo­phobia, blurring of vision and on exami­nation has a deep anterior chamber in the right eye. The left eye is normal. The diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Phacolytic glaucoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phacolytic glaucoma is a type of secondary open-angle glaucoma caused by leakage of lens proteins from a hypermature cataract. It typically presents with a deep anterior chamber, ciliary congestion, photophobia, and vision blurring in the affected eye.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of decreased vision and pain in his left eye. He reports a history of trauma to his right eye one week ago due to a workplace accident involving a metallic object. On examination, his right eye shows signs of recent trauma with corneal perforation. However, upon examination of the left eye, there are signs of severe inflammation, including uveitis and vitritis. The intraocular pressure is elevated, and there are no signs of trauma or infection in the left eye. What is the most likely diagnosis for the left eye?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sympathetic ophthalmitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sympathetic ophthalmia is a bilateral, granulomatous uveitis that occurs after penetrating trauma to one eye, affecting the uninjured eye due to an autoimmune response to exposed uveal antigens. It is a serious complication that requires prompt diagnosis and treatment to prevent vision loss.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is found to have ptosis of one eye with defective elevation of the eye. Opening the mouth causes elevation of the ptotic lid. The most likely clinical condition is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Congenital ptosis with phenomenon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Marcus Gunn jaw-winking syndrome is a type of congenital ptosis associated with the jaw-winking phenomenon. It involves an aberrant connection between the oculomotor and trigeminal nerves, leading to eyelid movement in response to jaw motion.
  • ➤ Marcus Gunn jaw-winking syndrome

questions.text: The action of superior rectus is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Elevation, intorsion, adduction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The superior rectus muscle performs elevation, intorsion, and adduction of the eye.
  • ➤ elevation, intorsion, and adduction

questions.text: Regarding the use of femtosecond laser for cataract surgery all of the following are true except:

options.label: A
options.text: It is especially useful for reducing phacoemulsification power needed in cases of mature dense cataract

options.label: B
options.text: It is particularly helpful for centring the rhexis in cases of patients undergoing Toric/Multifocal Intraocula Lens Implants

options.label: C
options.text: It is particularly helpful for small pupil cases

options.label: D
options.text: The order of performing the three main steps is as follows: first, anterior capsulotomy; second, lens fragmentation and or liquefaction; and third, the corneal incisions

questions.correct_answer: B. It is particularly helpful for centring the rhexis in cases of patients undergoing Toric/Multifocal Intraocula Lens Implants
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. It is particularly helpful for small pupil cases.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Femtosecond laser-assisted cataract surgery (FLACS) is beneficial for precise capsulotomy, reducing phacoemulsification energy, and centering the IOL, but it is not ideal for small pupil cases due to the need for good pupil dilation.
  • ➤ Femtosecond laser-assisted cataract surgery (FLACS)
  • ➤ not ideal for small pupil cases

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with painless red eye with coloured haloes and an IOP of 60 mmHg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Glaucomatocyclitic crisis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glaucomatocyclitic crisis (Posner-Schlossman syndrome) presents with a painless red eye, colored haloes, and very high IOP, typically without the severe pain associated with other forms of glaucoma.
  • ➤ Glaucomatocyclitic crisis (Posner-Schlossman syndrome)

questions.text: This is the fundus photo of a 50 year-old patient with history of diabetes mellitus for the past 8 years. The fundus in both eyes shows diabetic retinopathy. What is indicated by the black arrow in the photograph?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cotton wool spot

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cotton wool spots are white, fluffy lesions with poorly defined margins that indicate localized retinal ischemia. They are commonly seen in diabetic retinopathy as a sign of microvascular damage.
  • ➤ Cotton wool spots

questions.text: When light is flashed onto one eye, both the eyes’ pupils constrict as a response. This is known as the pupillary light reflex. Where is the center for this reflex located?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Midbrain

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The center for the pupillary light reflex is located in the midbrain , specifically involving the pretectal nucleus and Edinger-Westphal nuclei, which coordinate bilateral pupillary constriction in response to light.
  • ➤ center for the pupillary light reflex
  • ➤ midbrain

questions.text: 7-year-old boy presents to your clinic for an eye examination. His parents report complaints regarding his vision, that his schoolteacher has noted difficulty in reading the board during class. The boy was born full-term without any complications during pregnancy or delivery. He has no significant medical history, and there is no family history of eye diseases or significant vision problems. Visual acuity testing reveals that the patient's right eye has a visual acuity of 20/40, while his left eye has a visual acuity of 20/20. External examination of the eyes shows no abnormalities, and both pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light. Cycloplegic refraction demonstrates hyperopia of +4.00 D in the right eye and emmetropia in the left eye. Based on the clinical findings what further management steps would you recommend?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Refraction & Occlusion Therapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anisometropic amblyopia should be treated as early as possible with refraction and occlusion therapy to improve the vision in the weaker eye and prevent permanent vision impairment.
  • ➤ Anisometropic amblyopia
  • ➤ refraction and occlusion therapy

questions.text: The following finding is noted in a patient. What is the reason behind this pattern of deposition?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased affinity to endothelium in inferior cornea

options.label: D
options.text: Lipophilic nature of the suspended particles

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Convection currents

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The triangular pattern of keratic precipitates on the corneal endothelium (Arlt’s triangle) is due to convection currents in the aqueous humor, which move particles downward in a triangular pattern within the anterior chamber.
  • ➤ triangular pattern of keratic precipitates
  • ➤ convection currents

questions.text: In concomitant squint:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Primary deviation = Secondary deviation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In concomitant squint , the primary deviation is equal to the secondary deviation due to consistent alignment issues without muscle paralysis.
  • ➤ concomitant squint
  • ➤ primary deviation is equal to the secondary deviation

questions.text: The ophthalmic surgical instrument shown in the figure is used in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Syringing-Probing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lacrimal punctum dilator is specifically used for procedures involving the lacrimal drainage system, such as syringing and probing to manage lacrimal duct obstruction.
  • ➤ lacrimal punctum dilator
  • ➤ syringing and probing

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman presents with complains of a six month history of amenorrhea, galactorrhoea and an increasingly severe frontal headache. On further questioning she has had several near misses while driving recently but denies any visual problems. She has no past medical or surgical history and takes no regular medicines. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She lives with her husband and works as a teacher. She is happy in her work and not stressed. Neurological examination reveals a visual field defect but is otherwise normal. Given the likely diagnosis, which visual field defect is expected?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bitemporal hemianopia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of pituitary adenoma compressing the optic chiasm, bitemporal hemianopia is the expected visual field defect due to the involvement of the crossing nasal fibers of each optic nerve.
  • ➤ pituitary adenoma
  • ➤ bitemporal hemianopia

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency room with complaints of severe pain and swelling around his left eye after a recent accident while playing sports. Upon further inquiry, he reveals that he was struck directly on the eye with a fast-moving object. Considering the mechanism of injury described, which of the following is not typically associated with?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Exophthalmos

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An orbital blowout fracture is typically associated with endophthalmos, not exophthalmos , along with other signs such as diplopia, infraorbital nerve anesthesia, and a tear-drop sign on imaging.
  • ➤ endophthalmos, not exophthalmos

questions.text: Economic blindness is defined when visual acuity falls below:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) <6/60

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Economic blindness is defined when visual acuity falls below 6/60 , indicating significant impairment that affects economic productivity and daily functioning.
  • ➤ 6/60
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ The World Health Organization (WHO) classifies visual impairment based on visual acuity in the better-seeing eye, with the use of best possible correction. Here is the classification:
  • ➤ Normal Vision : Visual acuity of 6/6 to 6/18 . Mild Visual Impairment : Visual acuity of 6/18 to 6/60 . Moderate Visual Impairment (Low Vision): Visual acuity of 6/60 to 3/60 . Severe Visual Impairment (Severe Low Vision): Visual acuity of 3/60 to 1/60 . Blindness : Visual acuity of less than 3/60 or a corresponding visual field loss to less than 10 degrees in the better-seeing eye. Profound Blindness : Visual acuity of 1/60 or worse, or only light perception. Total Blindness : No light perception in either eye.
  • ➤ Normal Vision : Visual acuity of 6/6 to 6/18 .
  • ➤ Normal Vision
  • ➤ Visual acuity of 6/6 to 6/18 .
  • ➤ Visual acuity of 6/6 to 6/18 .
  • ➤ 6/6
  • ➤ 6/18
  • ➤ Mild Visual Impairment : Visual acuity of 6/18 to 6/60 .
  • ➤ Mild Visual Impairment
  • ➤ Visual acuity of 6/18 to 6/60 .
  • ➤ Visual acuity of 6/18 to 6/60 .
  • ➤ 6/18
  • ➤ 6/60
  • ➤ Moderate Visual Impairment (Low Vision): Visual acuity of 6/60 to 3/60 .
  • ➤ Moderate Visual Impairment
  • ➤ Visual acuity of 6/60 to 3/60 .
  • ➤ Visual acuity of 6/60 to 3/60 .
  • ➤ 6/60
  • ➤ 3/60
  • ➤ Severe Visual Impairment (Severe Low Vision): Visual acuity of 3/60 to 1/60 .
  • ➤ Severe Visual Impairment
  • ➤ Visual acuity of 3/60 to 1/60 .
  • ➤ Visual acuity of 3/60 to 1/60 .
  • ➤ 3/60
  • ➤ 1/60
  • ➤ Blindness : Visual acuity of less than 3/60 or a corresponding visual field loss to less than 10 degrees in the better-seeing eye.
  • ➤ Blindness
  • ➤ Visual acuity of less than 3/60 or a corresponding visual field loss to less than 10 degrees in the better-seeing eye.
  • ➤ Visual acuity of less than 3/60 or a corresponding visual field loss to less than 10 degrees in the better-seeing eye.
  • ➤ less than 3/60
  • ➤ Profound Blindness : Visual acuity of 1/60 or worse, or only light perception.
  • ➤ Profound Blindness
  • ➤ Visual acuity of 1/60 or worse, or only light perception.
  • ➤ Visual acuity of 1/60 or worse, or only light perception.
  • ➤ 1/60
  • ➤ Total Blindness : No light perception in either eye.
  • ➤ Total Blindness
  • ➤ No light perception in either eye.
  • ➤ No light perception in either eye.
  • ➤ No light perception

questions.text: Aqueous as compared to plasma has all more, except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Higher glucose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In comparison to plasma, the aqueous humor has lower glucose levels but higher levels of ascorbate, lactate, and pyruvate.
  • ➤ lower glucose levels

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient with a 15-year history of poorly controlled diabetes presents to the ophthalmology clinic with visual disturbances. On fundoscopic examination, you observe multiple hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and hard exudates in both eyes. However, one eye has a presentation more than the other. There is a lesion near the macula with vascularization and fluid accumulation, causing severe visual impairment. The patient reports no recent trauma. Which of the following findings is atypical for diabetic retinopathy in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Choroidal neovascular membrane formation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Choroidal neovascular membrane (CNVM) is atypical for diabetic retinopathy and is usually associated with conditions such as age-related macular degeneration, not diabetes.
  • ➤ Choroidal neovascular membrane (CNVM) is atypical for diabetic retinopathy

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology clinic complaining of decreased vision in his left eye following a recent blunt trauma to the face during a sporting event. Upon examination, you observe a ring-shaped pigment deposition on the anterior lens capsule of his left eye. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vossius ring

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A Vossius ring is a ring-shaped pigment deposition on the anterior lens capsule that occurs after blunt trauma to the eye, resulting from the impression of the iris pigment on the lens surface.
  • ➤ Vossius ring

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents with a history of progressive vision loss and night blindness. Upon examination, the patient displays characteristic retinal degeneration with peripheral bone spicule pigmentation. Which of the following syndromes is not likely associated with this clinical presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Marfans syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Marfan syndrome does not typically present with retinitis pigmentosa or associated retinal changes like bone spicule pigmentation, distinguishing it from syndromes commonly linked with retinal degeneration.
  • ➤ Marfan syndrome

questions.text: A 14-year-old obese girl presents with a headache. She states that the headache has been on and off for weeks and has a moderate intensity. She also states that she has had intermittent loss of vision for seconds at a time for the last two to three days. Physical examination reveals the above image. A non-contrast head CT scan is normal. What is the next best step in management?
questions.correct_answer: C. Lumbar puncture with opening pressure
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lumbar Puncture with opening pressure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of suspected idiopathic intracranial hypertension with signs of raised intracranial pressure (e.g., papilledema), a lumbar puncture with opening pressure measurement is the next best step for confirming the diagnosis, especially if imaging (e.g., CT) is unremarkable.
  • ➤ idiopathic intracranial hypertension
  • ➤ lumbar puncture with opening pressure measurement

questions.text: A 35-year-old male on slit lamp shows star shaped keratic precipitates & aqueous flare in his right eye. No synechiae but a complicated cataract is seen. The probable diagnosis would be:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Heterochromic iridocyclitis of Fuch’s

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fuchs' heterochromic iridocyclitis often presents with star-shaped keratic precipitates, aqueous flare, absence of synechiae, and a secondary cataract, which are distinctive features that help in its diagnosis.
  • ➤ Fuchs' heterochromic iridocyclitis

questions.text: 55-year-old male with a past medical history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes presents to the ophthalmologist's office complaining of progressive vision changes. On examination, fundoscopic evaluation reveals bilateral retinal hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and macular edema. The ophthalmologist diagnoses the patient with diabetic retinopathy. Give the diagnosis ,from the clinical photograph given below?

options.label: A
options.text: Cotton wool spots in the retina

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Retina after Pan-retinal photocoagulation (PRP)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The pattern of evenly distributed, pale spots across the retina is characteristic of Pan-retinal photocoagulation (PRP) , a treatment for advanced diabetic retinopathy aimed at reducing neovascularization risk by targeting the peripheral retina.
  • ➤ Pan-retinal photocoagulation (PRP)

questions.text: The test given below in the image is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Stereopsis test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Titmus Fly Test is a stereopsis test used to assess depth perception by presenting 3D images viewed through polarized glasses, making it useful in evaluating binocular vision and stereoscopic depth perception.
  • ➤ Titmus Fly Test
  • ➤ stereopsis test

questions.text: A 3 year old child presents with Right Convergent Squint of 6 months duration. What is appropriate management?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate surgical correction followed by amblyopia therapy

options.label: B
options.text: Proper refractive correction, amblyopia therapy followed by surgical correction

options.label: C
options.text: Prescribe glasses and defer surgery until the child is 5 yrs old

options.label: D
options.text: Botulinum toxin injection followed by occlusion therapy

questions.correct_answer: B. Proper refractive correction, amblyopia therapy followed by surgical correction
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Proper refractive correction, amblyopia therapy followed by surgical correction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of acquired esotropia in young children, proper refractive correction and amblyopia therapy should be initiated first , followed by surgical correction if necessary.
  • ➤ proper refractive correction and amblyopia therapy should be initiated first

questions.text: An elderly patient with a history of glaucoma presents with complaints of excessive daytime drowsiness. Upon reviewing their medication list, you note they are taking a combination of antiglaucoma medications. How would you approach the management of this patient's drowsiness while ensuring effective treatment for their glaucoma?

options.label: A
options.text: Discontinue Brimonidine eye drops and switch to an alternative antiglaucoma medication with less systemic absorption

options.label: B
options.text: Reduce the frequency of timolol eye drops administration and monitor the patient closely for improvement in drowsiness

options.label: C
options.text: Add a stimulant medication to counteract the drowsiness while continuing all medications for glaucoma management

options.label: D
options.text: Refer the patient to a specialist for further evaluation and consideration of alternative treatment options for both glaucoma management and management of drowsiness

questions.correct_answer: A. Discontinue Brimonidine eye drops and switch to an alternative antiglaucoma medication with less systemic absorption
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Discontinue Brimonidine eye drops and switch to an alternative antiglaucoma medication with less systemic absorption.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In elderly glaucoma patients experiencing daytime drowsiness, discontinuing brimonidine and considering an alternative with less central nervous system absorption is an effective approach to reduce drowsiness while maintaining glaucoma treatment.
  • ➤ discontinuing brimonidine and considering an alternative with less central nervous system absorption

questions.text: A patient presented with a sudden decrease in vision in right eye. While assessing his pupils, when light was shone in the left eye, both pupils constricted and when light was shone in the right eye, both pupils dilated. The likely abnormality is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Marcus Gunn pupil

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A Marcus Gunn pupil (RAPD) , identified by the swinging flashlight test, suggests an optic nerve defect or severe retinal pathology in the affected eye, resulting in an asymmetrical afferent response.
  • ➤ Marcus Gunn pupil (RAPD)
  • ➤ optic nerve defect or severe retinal pathology

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient reported with complaints of blurring of vision in his left eye for the past 2 weeks. He had a past history of central retinal vein occlusion in the left eye, which was diagnosed almost 3 months back. Slit lamp examination revealed rubeosis iridis in all the four quadrants. The intraocular pressure (IOP) in left eye is 72 mm of Hg. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neovascular glaucoma often occurs secondary to ischemic retinal diseases, such as central retinal vein occlusion, leading to neovascularization on the iris and in the angle, which obstructs aqueous outflow and causes a dramatic rise in intraocular pressure.
  • ➤ Neovascular glaucoma

questions.text: Ptosis in Horner's syndrome, is due to paralysis of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Muller's muscle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ptosis in Horner's syndrome is due to paralysis of Muller's muscle , which is responsible for a small degree of eyelid elevation and is innervated by sympathetic nerves.
  • ➤ Horner's syndrome
  • ➤ Muller's muscle
  • ➤ Additionally :
  • ➤ Additionally :
  • ➤ The appropriate surgical treatment for Horner's syndrome with ptosis is the Fasanella-Servat operation . Fasanella-Servat operation , also known as tarsomullarectomy , involves resecting part of Muller's muscle and the tarsal plate to correct mild ptosis by increasing eyelid elevation. LPS resection is used for managing simple congenital ptosis when LPS function is good. It strengthens the LPS muscle to improve eyelid elevation. If LPS action is poor, brow suspension is the preferred approach, where the brow is used to lift the eyelid.
  • ➤ The appropriate surgical treatment for Horner's syndrome with ptosis is the Fasanella-Servat operation .
  • ➤ Fasanella-Servat operation
  • ➤ Fasanella-Servat operation , also known as tarsomullarectomy , involves resecting part of Muller's muscle and the tarsal plate to correct mild ptosis by increasing eyelid elevation.
  • ➤ Fasanella-Servat operation
  • ➤ tarsomullarectomy
  • ➤ Muller's muscle
  • ➤ tarsal plate
  • ➤ LPS resection is used for managing simple congenital ptosis when LPS function is good. It strengthens the LPS muscle to improve eyelid elevation.
  • ➤ LPS resection
  • ➤ simple congenital ptosis
  • ➤ If LPS action is poor, brow suspension is the preferred approach, where the brow is used to lift the eyelid.
  • ➤ brow suspension

questions.text: 3 months old infant with watering lacrimal sac on pressing causes regurgitation of mucopus material. What is the appropriate treatment?

options.label: D
options.text: Massage with antibiotics up to age of 6 months

questions.correct_answer: D. Massage with antibiotics up to age of 6 months
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Massage with antibiotics up to age of 6 months

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a 3-month-old infant with symptoms of congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction, Crigler massage combined with antibiotic drops is the first-line treatment up to 6 months, as spontaneous resolution is common within this period.
  • ➤ Crigler massage combined with antibiotic drops

questions.text: A cataract surgeon noticed zonular dehiscence in a patient preoperatively of less than 2 clock hours. What precaution can be taken during surgery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Capsular tension rings (CTR)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of zonular dehiscence during cataract surgery, Capsular Tension Rings (CTR) are used to stabilize the capsular bag, providing support for safe lens implantation and minimizing the risk of capsular instability.
  • ➤ Capsular Tension Rings (CTR)

questions.text: Identify the given image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Trabeculectomy Bleb

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A trabeculectomy bleb is a characteristic post-surgical finding after trabeculectomy, appearing as a translucent, elevated structure near the limbus and is commonly used to manage glaucoma by reducing intraocular pressure.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to your clinic with complaints of gradual blurring of vision over the past year. Upon examination, you notice a distortion of the corneal reflex at the center of the cornea, along with thinning of the cornea in the center. There is evidence of Munson's sign. Which of the following findings would you expect in the refractive error of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Myopic refractive error

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Keratoconus typically leads to a myopic refractive error due to the bulging and thinning of the cornea, with secondary irregular astigmatism often following.

questions.text: A 55-year-old diabetic male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset severe eye pain, redness, and decreased vision in his right eye over the past 24 hours. He recently underwent cataract surgery in the affected eye. On examination, the right eye is injected, and the cornea is hazy with hypopyon noted. Which of the following is the most important factor in the prevention of this complication of cataract surgery?

options.label: B
options.text: One week antibiotic therapy prior to surgery

questions.correct_answer: A. Preoperative preparation with povidone iodine
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Preoperative preparation with povidone iodine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Preoperative preparation with povidone iodine is the most important step in preventing postoperative endophthalmitis following cataract surgery.

questions.text: Identify the field defect:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bjerrum scotoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bjerrum scotomas are arc-shaped visual field defects associated with glaucomatous optic nerve damage, following the nerve fiber layer’s path and usually seen in early to moderate glaucoma.

questions.text: In retinal detachment, fluid accumulates between:

options.label: A
options.text: Outer plexiform layer and inner nuclear layer

options.label: B
options.text: Neurosensory retina and layer of retinal pigment epithelium

options.label: C
options.text: Nerve fiber layer and rest of retina

options.label: D
options.text: Retinal pigment epithelium and Bruch’s membrane

questions.correct_answer: B. Neurosensory retina and layer of retinal pigment epithelium
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Neurosensory retina and layer of retinal pigment epithelium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In retinal detachment, fluid accumulates between the neurosensory retina and the retinal pigment epithelium, leading to separation and potential vision loss if untreated.

questions.text: Steroids are contraindicated in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Dendritic ulcer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Steroids are contraindicated in dendritic ulcers (herpes simplex virus-related corneal ulcers) as they can worsen the infection, potentially leading to a larger geographic ulcer and corneal damage.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy came to consult you in your OPD where he gave history of trauma to his right eye. On carrying out slit-lamp examination you see a superficial injury on the cornea. Usually, in injuries involving only the corneal epithelium, the stratified squamous epithelium rapidly regenerates because of the presence of stem cells. Where are the Palisades of Vogt containing the stem cells located?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Limbus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Palisades of Vogt, located at the limbus, contain stem cells essential for corneal epithelial regeneration after superficial injuries.

questions.text: The only extraocular muscle which does not arise from the apex of the orbit is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Inferior oblique

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The inferior oblique is the only extraocular muscle that originates from the anterior part of the orbit rather than the orbital apex, allowing it to elevate and extort the eye.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with a history of diabetes presents with complaints of blurry vision after cataract surgery. Fundus fluorescein angiography reveals a characteristic 'flower petals' appearance in the macula region? What is he most likely suffering from?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cystoid macular edema

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cystoid macular edema (CME), also known as Irvine-Gass syndrome, is a common complication following cataract surgery, particularly in diabetic patients, and is characterized by a 'flower petal' appearance on fundus fluorescein angiography.

questions.text: This is the fundus picture of a 60 year-old male patient who presented with sudden loss of vision in the right eye. He is a known hypertensive and diabetic. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Central retinal vein obstruction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Central retinal vein obstruction (CRVO) presents with widespread retinal hemorrhages, edema, and dilated veins, often seen in patients with risk factors like hypertension and diabetes, and results in sudden vision loss.

questions.text: A patient presents with head tilted to the right side. On examination, he has left hypertropia which increases on looking to the right side. The muscle most likely to be paralyzed is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Left superior oblique

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of vertical strabismus with a head tilt and worsening on lateral gaze, use Park’s three-step test to identify the affected muscle. For left hypertropia with worsening in right gaze and a compensatory head tilt to the right, the left superior oblique is likely paralyzed.

questions.text: A 19-year-old young girl with previous history of repeated pain over medial canthus and chronic use of nasal decongestants presented with abrupt onset of fever and chills and rigor, diplopia on lateral gaze, moderate proptosis and chemosis. On examination, optic disc is congested. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cavernous sinus thrombosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cavernous sinus thrombosis is characterized by systemic infectious symptoms (fever, chills, rigor), ocular symptoms (diplopia, proptosis, chemosis), and optic disc congestion. It is a serious condition requiring rapid diagnosis and treatment due to the risk of complications from infection spreading from facial or sinus regions.

questions.text: Most common cause of blindness in children is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vitamin A deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin A deficiency is the most common cause of blindness in children, especially in areas with high malnutrition rates. Public health interventions to prevent vitamin A deficiency are essential to reduce the risk of blindness in these populations.
  • ➤ Remember:
  • ➤ Remember:
  • ➤ In India, Vitamin A deficiency is the leading cause due to higher rates of malnutrition. Globally, cataract is the most common cause of blindness in children.
  • ➤ In India, Vitamin A deficiency is the leading cause due to higher rates of malnutrition.
  • ➤ In India, Vitamin A deficiency
  • ➤ Globally, cataract is the most common cause of blindness in children.
  • ➤ Globally, cataract

questions.text: The given image pupil occurs in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Iridodialysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A D-shaped pupil is characteristic of iridodialysis , which occurs when the iris is torn away from its normal attachment to the ciliary body, usually due to trauma.
  • ➤ iridodialysis

questions.text: A value of 0.75D was deduced from the retinoscopy reading as a part of drug correction. The likely drug used was?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cyclopentolate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tropicamide, a mild cycloplegic agent, is likely to result in a residual accommodation of about 0.75D on retinoscopy, making it the preferred choice when only mild cycloplegia is needed for refractive assessments.

questions.text: A 88 year old patient underwent cataract surgery for a hypermature cataract and landed up with complication of Aphakia- which of the following was Best site where intraocular lens should ideally have been fitted:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Capsular bag

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For optimal visual outcomes in cataract surgery, the ideal location for intraocular lens (IOL) implantation is the capsular bag . When the bag is intact, it provides the best support and positioning for the IOL, resulting in improved stability and visual quality.
  • ➤ capsular bag

questions.text: True about cortical blindness is:

options.label: A
options.text: Direct and consensual reflexes are present in both eyes

options.label: B
options.text: Direct and consensual reflexes are absent in both eyes

options.label: C
options.text: Direct reflex is present but consensual reflex is absent on the normal side

options.label: D
options.text: Direct reflex is absent but consensual reflex is present on the normal side

questions.correct_answer: A. Direct and consensual reflexes are present in both eyes
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Direct and consensual reflexes are present in both eyes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cortical blindness, the direct and consensual pupillary reflexes are preserved in both eyes because the pupillary pathways diverge early in the visual system, bypassing the visual cortex. This condition is characterized by a lack of visual perception with intact pupillary responses.
  • ➤ direct and consensual pupillary reflexes are preserved

questions.text: True about telecanthus is:

options.label: A
options.text: Increase in intercanthal distance with normal interpupillary distance

options.label: B
options.text: Widely separated medial wall of orbits

options.label: C
options.text: Increased intercanthal distance with increased interpupillary distance

questions.correct_answer: A. Increase in intercanthal distance with normal interpupillary distance
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Increase in intercanthal distance with normal interpupillary distance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Telecanthus is defined by an increased intercanthal distance with a normal interpupillary distance, distinguishing it from hypertelorism, which involves an increased bony distance between the orbits, affecting both intercanthal and interpupillary distances.
  • ➤ Telecanthus

questions.text: Which is not a clinical feature of right sided VIth nerve palsy:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Face turn to left

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In right-sided VIth nerve palsy, the clinical features include a medial convergent squint, inability to abduct the right eye, and diplopia. To compensate, patients often turn their face to the right (the side of the palsy) to maintain binocular vision and reduce double vision.
  • ➤ right

questions.text: A 3-day-old new-born presents with bilateral eye redness and purulent discharge. On examination, the infant has eyelid edema and conjunctival injection with mucopurulent discharge. Which of the following pathogens is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Chlamydia trachomatis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chlamydia trachomatis (serotypes D–K) is now the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum, presenting with bilateral eye redness, edema, and mucopurulent discharge in newborns. Early identification and treatment are crucial to prevent further complications.
  • ➤ Chlamydia trachomatis

questions.text: A young male presents with central scotoma in the left eye. His right eye showed 6/6 vision though with metamorphopsia. On examination there is focal foveal detachment in the left eye. What should be the next step?

options.label: C
options.text: Inquire about trauma to the other eye

questions.correct_answer: B. Inquire about use of steroids
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Inquire about use of steroids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases where a young patient presents with central scotoma, metamorphopsia, and foveal detachment, consider Central Serous Retinopathy (CSR) . Always inquire about steroid use , as it is a known risk factor that can contribute to this condition.
  • ➤ Central Serous Retinopathy (CSR)
  • ➤ steroid use

questions.text: A mother brought her 3-year-old child with cataract for second opinion. The child appears othrotropic and fine. What will be the management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cataract surgery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In pediatric cases, cataract surgery is usually recommended if there is any suspicion that a cataract may impact visual development, even if the child appears to be orthotropic and symptomatically fine. This is because undiagnosed visual impairment can lead to amblyopia, which is harder to treat as the child ages.

questions.text: Which of following drug combinations is not generally used in glaucoma?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pilocarpine + Latanoprost

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pilocarpine and Latanoprost are not typically combined in glaucoma therapy due to their combined potential to increase intraocular inflammation and their differing dosing schedules, which complicate their use together.
  • ➤ Pilocarpine and Latanoprost

questions.text: All are true regarding cornea, except:

options.label: B
options.text: Majority of the refraction occurs at the air-cornea interface

options.label: C
options.text: With the rule astigmatism is seen because the vertical meridian is steeper than the horizontal

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Refractive index is 1.334

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The refractive index of the cornea is approximately 1.376 , while 1.334 is the refractive index of the vitreous. This distinction is important in understanding ocular refractive properties.
  • ➤ refractive index of the cornea is approximately 1.376

questions.text: A child weighing 8 Kg has Bitot's spots in both eyes. Which is the most ap schedule of vitamin A for the child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 100,000 units IM on days 1, 2, 14

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a child weighing 8 kg with signs of vitamin A deficiency, such as Bitot's spots, the appropriate vitamin A IM dosing is 100,000 units on days 1, 2, and 14 . This schedule ensures optimal absorption and effective treatment for the deficiency.
  • ➤ 100,000 units on days 1, 2, and 14

questions.text: A patient presents to emergency with tremors , difficulty in speech , depression & mood swings . O/E he has hepatomegaly & following sign on eye examination. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Wilson disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wilson disease is associated with the Kayser-Fleischer ring around the cornea, and its symptoms include neurological and psychiatric manifestations due to copper accumulation, as well as liver enlargement (hepatomegaly).
  • ➤ Wilson disease
  • ➤ Kayser-Fleischer ring

questions.text: A patient of old standing diabetes mellitus noticed sudden onset muscae volitanes. On examination, the red reflex was dim, with no details of fundus could be seen. He might have:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vitreous haemorrhage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a diabetic patient with sudden floaters and a dim red reflex, vitreous hemorrhage due to proliferative diabetic retinopathy is highly likely. This results from fragile new vessels that bleed into the vitreous, obstructing the view of the retina.
  • ➤ vitreous hemorrhage

questions.text: ETDRS chart is used for vision evaluation in diabetic patients. What does ETDRS for?

options.label: A
options.text: Extended treatment for diabetic retinopathy study

options.label: B
options.text: Early treatment for diabetic retinopathy study

options.label: C
options.text: Emergency treatment for diabetic retinopathy study

options.label: D
options.text: Emerging treatment for diabetic retinopathy study

questions.correct_answer: B. Early treatment for diabetic retinopathy study
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Early treatment for diabetic retinopathy study

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ETDRS refers to the Early Treatment for Diabetic Retinopathy Study , which has established key guidelines in the treatment of diabetic retinopathy and the use of standardized visual acuity charts for patient monitoring.
  • ➤ ETDRS
  • ➤ Early Treatment for Diabetic Retinopathy Study

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with watering from his left eye since one year. Syringing revealed a patent drainage system. Rest of ocular examination was normal. A provisional diagnosis of lacrimal pump failure was made. Confirmation of the diagnosis would be by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dacryoscintigraphy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dacryoscintigraphy is the diagnostic test of choice to confirm lacrimal pump failure, as it assesses the effectiveness of the pump mechanism by tracking dye movement through the drainage system.
  • ➤ Dacryoscintigraphy

questions.text: Mydriasis is present in all the following except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pontine haemorrhage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pontine haemorrhage is associated with pinpoint pupils, whereas conditions like third nerve lesions, Datura poisoning, and the fourth stage of anesthesia result in mydriasis.

questions.text: A young patient with history of using glasses for the past 10 years comes with complains of photopsia and flashes in the right eye. Which of the following tests should be done?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Indirect ophthalmoscopy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Indirect ophthalmoscopy is essential for examining peripheral retinal lesions, particularly in patients with photopsia and a history of refractive errors, to rule out retinal detachment.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology clinic complaining of decreased vision in his right eye following a history of trauma. On examination, you note a dense scar of the cornea with incarceration of the iris. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Adherent Leucoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adherent leucoma involves a corneal scar with incarceration of the iris, typically following trauma, differentiating it from other forms of leucoma or staphyloma.

questions.text: A 7-year-old male presents with 6/6 vision in the right eye and hand movements vision in the left eye. On fundoscopy, the right eye was normal. The left eye showed retinal detachment, subretinal yellowish exudates and telangiectatic vessels. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Coats' disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Coats' disease is a unilateral retinal vascular disorder in young males, presenting with telangiectatic vessels, subretinal exudates, and retinal detachment, often leading to leukocoria.

questions.text: A recurrent chalazion should be subjected to histopathological examination to rule out the possibility of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sebaceous cell Carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recurrent chalazions warrant histopathological examination to rule out sebaceous cell carcinoma, an aggressive eyelid malignancy that can mimic benign lesions.

questions.text: Krukenberg spindle is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Corneal Endothelium-Pigmentary glaucoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Krukenberg spindle is a pigmented deposit on the corneal endothelium, typically seen in pigmentary glaucoma.

questions.text: Regarding cataract surgery for patients with diabetes mellitus (DM):

options.label: A
options.text: Diabetic retinopathy (DR) must always be treated before cataract surgery is undertaken

options.label: B
options.text: Elevated blood sugar on the day of surgery is a contra-indication to proceeding

options.label: D
options.text: Uncomplicated cataract surgery is a proven independent risk factor for progression of diabetic retinopathy

questions.correct_answer: C. Pupil dilation may be reduced
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pupil dilation may be reduced

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diabetic patients may experience reduced pupil dilation due to neuropathy, which should be accounted for when planning cataract surgery.

questions.text: Position of the lens in Marfan' s syndrome is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Supero-temporal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Marfan's syndrome, the lens is typically dislocated in a supero-temporal (upward and outward) position due to weakened zonules.

questions.text: Lagophthalmos can occur in all of the following except
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 5th cranial nerve paralysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lagophthalmos is commonly caused by 7th cranial nerve paralysis, thyrotoxic exophthalmos, and symblepharon, but it is not associated with 5th cranial nerve paralysis.

questions.text: In grades of binocular vision what the encircled figure denote:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Fusion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fusion is a critical step in binocular vision, allowing the brain to merge images from both eyes into a single perception.

questions.text: The type of optic atrophy that follows retro-bulbar neuritis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Primary optic atrophy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Retro-bulbar neuritis typically leads to primary optic atrophy due to the absence of initial optic disc swelling.

questions.text: A malnourished child from poor socioeconomic status, residing in overcrowded & dirty areas presents with a nodule around limbus with hyperemia of adjacent conjunctiva. Other significant findings were axillary & cervical lymphadenopathy:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Phlyctenular conjunctivitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phlyctenular conjunctivitis presents with nodules around the limbus and adjacent conjunctival hyperemia, commonly in children from poor socioeconomic conditions, and may be associated with lymphadenopathy due to systemic immune response.

questions.text: Which of the following glaucoma is least likely to respond to medical therapy alone?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Phacolytic glaucoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phacolytic glaucoma is less likely to respond to medical therapy alone due to the presence of lens protein leakage and typically requires surgical intervention for definitive treatment

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient is scheduled for surgery to correct myopia. The surgeon plans to use a laser for corneal reshaping. Which of the following laser wavelengths (in nanometers) is most commonly used for shaping the cornea in refractive surgery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 193

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The 193 nm excimer laser is the gold standard for corneal reshaping in refractive surgeries such as LASIK due to its precision and minimal collateral thermal damage.

questions.text: The percentage of tropcamide eye drops is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 0.5%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The standard concentration of tropicamide eye drops for pupil dilation is 0.5%.

questions.text: All of the following are given global prominence in the VISION 2020 goal, except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Glaucoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The VISION 2020 initiative prioritizes conditions such as cataract, refractive errors, trachoma, and childhood blindness but does not give the same level of global prominence to glaucoma.

questions.text: Identify the test being performed in the image below:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tonometry

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tonometry is used to measure intraocular pressure, and the Tono-Pen is a handheld device often employed for this purpose, particularly in cases of irregular or edematous corneas.

questions.text: Which of the Antiglaucoma medications is notorious for the side effect shown in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Netarsudil

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Netarsudil, an antiglaucoma medication, can cause corneal verticillata or vortex keratopathy, a whorl-like pattern of deposits in the corneal epithelium.

questions.text: A 68-year-old hospitalized woman is evaluated due to decreased vision in the left eye. The patient has a history of advanced ovarian cancer and has been treated with combination chemotherapy. Three weeks ago, she was admitted to the hospital with small bowel obstruction. There was no improvement with nonoperative management, so she underwent exploratory laparotomy and bowel resection 14 days ago. The postoperative course was complicated by an anastomotic leak. The patient is receiving total parenteral nutrition and piperacillin-tazobactam. Over the past 2days, she has had floaters and progressive blurring of the vision in the left eye. The patient reports no eye pain or headache. Temperature is 38 C (100.4 F), blood pressure is 122/80 mm Hg, and pulse is96/min. Left eye visual acuity is decreased, and fundoscopy reveals fluffy, yellow-white chorioretinal lesions with ill-defined borders. The central venous catheter site has no erythema or tenderness. There is no discharge from the abdominal incisions. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's ocular symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fungal endophthalmitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fungal endophthalmitis, particularly due to Candida species, should be suspected in immunocompromised or critically ill patients with systemic risk factors who present with ocular symptoms and characteristic chorioretinal lesions.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to a sudden onset of severe pain in her left eye with blurred vision, nausea, and vomiting. The symptoms began a few minutes ago, while she was watching a movie in a nearby theater. Her temperature is 36.8C (98.4F),blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg, pulse is82/min, and respirations are 14/min. Examination reveals decreased visual acuity. Her left eye appears red, with a hazy cornea, shallow anterior chamber, and dilated, fixed pupil. Her left eye is stony hard to touch. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute angle closure glaucoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute angle closure glaucoma is an emergency characterized by sudden eye pain, a red eye, hazy cornea, shallow anterior chamber, and a dilated, fixed pupil. It requires prompt treatment to lower intraocular pressure and prevent vision loss.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman presents with a 2-year history of a painless, progressively enlarging mass in the central aspect of the upper eyelid. This has resulted in distortion of the eyelid margin and loss of eyelashes. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Basal cell carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Basal cell carcinoma is the most common and likely diagnosis for a slow-growing, painless mass on the eyelid with margin distortion and loss of eyelashes in elderly patients.
